A rare, nearly 2,000-year-old gold coin under a magnifying glass, at the Antiquities Authority office inside the Israel Museum in Jerusalem.

Israel’s Antiquities Authority says a hiker has found a rare, nearly 2,000-year-old gold coin.

The authority said on Monday that the ancient coin appears to be only the second of its kind to have been found. It said London’s British Museum possesses the other coin. The coin, from the year A.D. 107, bears the image of Augustus, the first emperor of the Roman Empire.

It was minted as part of a series of coins honouring Roman rulers. Antiquities Authority official Donald T. Ariel said the coin may have paid part of the salary of a Roman soldier. — AP
title: Israeli hiker finds 2,000-year-old gold coin
